dict.string: Downloads the currently playing (in Safari) YouTube video.

WORKFLOWPATH="`pwd`"
osascript << _EOF_ on FileExists(theFile) -- (String) as Boolean tell application "System Events" if exists file theFile then return true else return false end if end tell end FileExists
if FileExists("$WORKFLOWPATH/youtube-dl") tell application "Safari" set theURL to URL of current tab of window 1 set theTitle to name of front document set AppleScript's text item delimiters to " - YouTube" set theTitle2 to text item 1 of theTitle set theTitle3 to ((characters 2 thru end of theTitle2) as string) end tell
if theURL contains "youtube.com" display notification "Download started: '" & theTitle2 & "'" do shell script "afplay \"/System/Library/Sounds/Hero.aiff\"" set results to do shell script "cd $HOME/Movies && \"$WORKFLOWPATH/youtube-dl\" --no-progress " & theURL display notification "Download complete: '" & theTitle2 & "'"
do shell script "afplay \"/System/Library/Sounds/Hero.aiff\"" display dialog "Downloaded video '" & theTitle2 & "' to the Movies folder. Results:" & return & return & results buttons {"OK"} default button 1 with title "Success" with icon note giving up after 5 else display notification "Error: not a video: '" & theTitle2 & "'" do shell script "afplay \"/System/Library/Sounds/Basso.aiff\"" display dialog "This does not appear to be a YouTube video." buttons {"OK"} default button 1 with title "Error" with icon stop giving up after 5 end if else display notification "Error: youtube-dl not installed."
do shell script "afplay \"/System/Library/Sounds/Basso.aiff\"" display dialog "You do not have youtube-dl installed. Install Homebrew (http://brew.sh) then at a Terminal prompt type 'brew install youtube-dl'." buttons {"OK"} default button 1 with title "Error" with icon stop end if
tell application "Safari" activate end tell _EOF_

I've put together a simple workflow to download YouTube videos. This only works for Safari so far (if you can add additional browser support, I would appreciate a patch.) Simply browse to a video in Safari, and either activate Alfred and enter "ytdl", or use the hotkey Cmd+Option+Ctrl+Y. The video will be saved in your Movies folder.
